content:
The Act may be cited as the "Violence Against Children Act of 2003". Congress finds that children under 18 make up a significant portion of crime victims, with high rates of sex crimes and kidnapping. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more likely to be victims of violent crime than adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, with 1,200 children dying from abuse annually and 879,000 being victims. Child abuse has lasting negative effects on children and families, leading to delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased risk of domestic violence in adulthood. Local agencies often lack resources to support children and families in need, leading to issues such as delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased risk of domestic violence. Failure to pay child support contributes to neglect, resulting in children living in poverty and facing challenges in education, healthcare, and housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN

SEC. 101. ENHANCED PENALTIES. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on violence against children. It specifies penalties for injuring or attempting to injure a person under 18 years of age, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The new section on violence against children in Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code, specifies penalties for injuring or attempting to injure a person under 18 years of age. Harsher penalties apply if the offense involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder, especially if it occurs across state lines or involves the use of firearms or other weapons that have traveled in interstate or foreign commerce. The text discusses penalties under section 1111 of title 18, United States Code, for offenses also covered under that section. The chapter analysis for chapter 110 of the same title is amended accordingly. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for federal crimes against children under 18. The Comptroller General will review state laws on crimes against children and report findings to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 102. Enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of State, tribal, or local governments. Priority is given to cases involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states or rural jurisdictions with limited resources. The Attorney General prioritizes assisting in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors, especially cases involving offenders who have committed crimes in multiple states or rural jurisdictions with limited resources. Federal assistance is provided to state and local law enforcement under Title II through grant programs. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in developing and strengthening effective law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children. Grants provide personnel, training, technical assistance, data collection, and equipment for apprehension and prosecution of offenders. Training for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel is emphasized, along with the development of specialized units targeting crimes against children. The curr_chunk focuses on enhancing efforts to prevent, identify, and respond to crimes against children. This includes developing effective police and prosecution policies, implementing data collection systems, and promoting collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the application process for grants under a program aimed at addressing crimes against children. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments must submit applications to the Attorney General, outlining the purposes for which the grant is sought. The focus is on enhancing cross-communication between law enforcement and child services agencies and developing programs for Indian tribes dealing with crimes against children. The unit of local government applying for a grant must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant. They also need to consult with victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes, and certify the receipt of any Federal funds. The unit of local government applying for a grant must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant. They also need to consult with victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes, certify the receipt of any Federal funds, and ensure compliance with specified sections. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 for this purpose. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to provide education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including seminars, hotlines, training programs, and awareness efforts. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children, including awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. States, tribal governments, local governments, or NGOs must submit an application to the Attorney General to receive a grant under this section. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Applicants must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds, and demonstrate a plan for implementation. The grant recipient must consult and coordinate with victim services programs experienced in helping children who are victims of crimes, ensuring that the services provided are effective and appropriate. The grant recipient must have experience in providing services to victims of crimes against children and certify that federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for activities funded under this section. The Attorney General may waive this requirement for nongovernmental organizations in extraordinary circumstances. The government or nongovernmental organization must comply with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 for this section. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years of this Act.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must utilize the National Incident-Based Reporting System for statistical data collection.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under section 202 must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously, collect family medical history with parent approval, search missing person databases after relinquishment, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law within 3 years of this Act. The State must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn anonymously with a hospital employee, collect family medical history, search missing person databases, and publicize the Safe Haven law. An exception allows denial of anonymity if the newborn shows signs of abuse or harm. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. States must submit a report on their child welfare services program within 180 days of this Act, detailing record-keeping and child well-being verification processes. The General Accounting Office will also report to Congress on State practices in the child welfare program. The curr_chunk discusses how States are maintaining records and verifying the well-being of children in their care, the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, best practices implemented by States, and recommendations for legislative changes by Congress in the child welfare system. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend the current Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for those not receiving owed child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for Federal tax purposes.
